ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

Sameness/Need for Routine - Comments
On average, how many days last week was your child bothered by anxiety concerns?
Notes: 0=None (No anxious symptoms); 1=Minimal (1 or 2 days a week); 2=Mild (3 or 4 days a week); 3=Moderate (5 or 6 days a week); 4=Severe (Daily); 5=Extreme (Multiple times per day)

ElementDescription: How distressing were the anxiety symptoms? How long did episodes last, what did they look like?
Notes: 0=None (No anxiety symptoms); 1=Minimal (Transient episodes lasting only a few seconds or minutes, not disturbing); 2=Mild (Episodes last several minutes to an hour. Mildly disturbing. Borderline clinical significance); 3=Moderate (Episodes last minutes to hours. Clearly nervous in anticipation of upcoming events or anxiety provoking situation(s). Often unable to manage anxiety. Clinically significant); 4=Severe (Episodes last for extended periods of time (hours). Prominent distress in anticipation of upcoming events or anxiety provoking situation(s). Usually unable to manage anxiety); 5=Extreme (Near constant state of anxiety in anticipation of upcoming events or anxiety-provoking situation(s). Almost totally unable to manage anxiety. Marked impact on well-being.)

ElementDescription: What places/situations did your child avoid due to anxiety? How often?
Notes: 0=None (Did not avoid any situation(s) due to anxiety); 1=Minimal (Rarely avoids situation(s) due to anxiety. If present, did not affect well-being); 2=Mild (Occasional avoidance. Isolated to a few situations. Borderline clinical significance); 3=Moderate (Some of the time. Avoids a few situations or consistently avoids a single situation. Avoids at least one important situation due to anxiety. Clinically significant); 4=Severe (Most of the time. Avoids many situations and more than one important situation); 5=Extreme (Almost always. Consistently avoids many or most situations. Major issue)

ElementDescription: How did anxiety symptoms affect the family? Did routine events take longer? Were anxiety symptoms the source of conflict at home?
Notes: 0=None (No interference); 1=Minimal (Interference in family relationships was rare. Limited interference in everyday life at home); 2=Mild (Sporadic interference in family relationships or performance at home. Slight interference in everyday life at home. Borderline clinical significance); 3=Moderate (Frequent interference (more days than not) in family relationships. Anxiety has negative impact in at least one area of family life. Performance of everyday tasks at home or interaction with family members is affected. Clinically significant); 4=Severe (Interference at home occurs most of the time (e.g.=daily). Marked interference in everyday life at home or family relationships); 5=Extreme (Interference in family relationships and everyday life occur multiple times a day. Totally or almost totally unable to maintain appropriate family relationships and/or function at home.)

ElementDescription: How did your child''s anxiety symptoms affect homework, extracurricular activities or social interactions outside the home?
Notes: 0=None (No interference); 1=Minimal (Interference in relationships outside the home is rare or transient. Limited interference in tasks of everyday living outside the home); 2=Mild (Sporadic interference in relationships outside of the home. Interference in usual activities is confined to one relationship or situation. Borderline clinical significance); 3=Moderate (Frequent interference (more days than not) in relationships outside the home. Interference is evident in at least one important area of everyday life. Clinically significant); 4=Severe (Interference is evident most of the time (e.g.=daily). Marked interference in multiple relationships with peers or adults and in everyday activities outside the home); 5=Extreme (Interference always or almost always (e.g.=multiple times daily). Marked interference with relationships and performance of routine activities outside of home.)
